title: Question for Paul
text: Paul:  I am going to help a friend build one of these (already have one for myself) and I was thinking about doing the same thing with the Capita brackets you suggested.  However I  am hoping you can clarify something for me in regards to mounting them.  For the end brackets where you used T-nuts, did you slide brackets in towards the center so that the T-nuts could be used underneath the thinner top side of the bookcase (ie sandwiching the bookcase between the T-nut and the bracket) or did you somehow embed them into the thicker end panel of the bookcase?  I can't see how the second scenario could work so I'm guessing the first but wanted to be sure.  Thanks!

author: Paul
title: Thank you for this great standing desk design!
text:
I'm standing in front of mine now as I write this!  I've been looking for a standing desk for almost 2 years now and finally came across your design a couple of weeks ago!  The only thing I did differently was, instead of drilling through the table top and having bolts showing on top, I mounted the threaded shaft of the Capita brackets through the bookcase and used tee nuts on the end brackets to secure them.  For the middle two brackets, because of the 'shelf' that runs down the middle of the bookcase they would be offset slightly to one side.  What I did to prevent this was, I just drilled in as far as necessary so the threaded shaft fit in enough to be flush with the bookcase, then used construction adhesive to secure the bracket to the bookcase.  The only thing that bugs me is the fact that the table top is hollow in spots and I'm a little worried about how long the screws they provide will hold in it.  I didn't try using the construction adhesive on those but if they start loosening, I might have to use it on them.

Anyway, I was so excited about getting this desk built, that I decided to redo my whole office with the Expedit bookcases!  I also picked up a bunch of those boxes from IKEA that are designed to fit in the cubby holes of the bookcases, so I can hide all of my crap inside them!

Thanks again!

author: Charley (Guest)
title: Dunn & Dunn!
text:
Hi. Just letting you know I built a desk using your design. Exactly the same, just using one Expedit, and a shorter Vika Amon top. So, half as wide, in other words.

The only difference was, for the front Capita brackets I kept the round discs on top of the brackets to make the desk flat back to front. I hacksawed the bolts down and drilled two pilot holes in the front underside of the desk, and the cut bolts popped into those. You gotta be careful with those Vika Amon tops, as they are hollow in the middle.

BTW, I didn't use epoxy, but I did squeeze some "no more nails" down the screw holes to give the screws some better purchase. Both the Expedit and the Vita Amon tops are made of a composite wood material which screws can turn to sawdust over time. Especially if you over tighten them! I used a manual screwdriver for the final turns, just to make sure the drill didn't gouge the wood.

Thanks again for your design. The cost of the project for me was $200 (Australian)
